node.title: PM urged to protect gay students, teachers as he prepares to introduce religious discrimination bill
node.alt: Close-up shot of hands clasped together as if in prayer over an old book with blurred text, that could be a religious text.
node.description: The Prime Minister will say the proposed law will protect religious Australians against "cancel culture". However,Â he is also being urged to act immediately to ensure gay students and teachers cannot be fired or expelled.
node.content: ["The Prime Minister is set to introduce the religious discrimination bill to parliament today, but at the same time he is being urged by moderate Liberal MPs to act immediately to make sure gay students and teachers are better protected.", "Years after\u00a0the original draft was written, Scott Morrison will introduce the watered-down legislation this morning and will say the bring proposed law will bring \"clarity\" and \"confidence\" that \"Australians of faith will be protected from discrimination\".", "\"Many people from various religious traditions are concerned about the lack of religious protection against the prevalence of cancel culture\u00a0on campuses and in Australian corporate life,\" he is expected to say.", "\"A Sikh should not be discriminated against because of the turban they wear. Nor a Maronite because of the cross around their neck. Nor a Muslim employee who keeps a prayer mat in the bottom drawer of their desk at work.\"", "The law is seeking to protect Australians who make \"statements of belief\" from existing state-based discrimination laws, but only if those statements do not \"threaten, intimidate, harass or vilify a person or group\".", "Under the law, religious schools and organisations would be allowed to give preference and prioritise the employment and enrolment of people from the same faith, but the institutions would have to have a clear public policy that explained\u00a0how religious views would\u00a0be enforced.", "While many religious organisations have welcomed the new bill, LGBTIQ advocacy groups have voiced concerns about it, particularly about what it may mean for gay students and staff at religious schools.", "Some moderate Liberals are urging Mr Morrison to act on a 2018 promise to change the sex discrimination act to\u00a0protect students from being expelled because of their sexuality.", "The government has already confirmed the act will be reviewed but backbencher Trent Zimmerman said that would take too long.", "\"It is disturbing that still today a school could exercise those rights to expel a student because of their sexuality.\"", "Assistant Attorney-General Amanda Stoker said the review was something the government was still \"committed to pursue\"."]
